docs.lead_paragraph: There’s a growing sense among progressives that they have been duped by President Obama. And that’s why the mixed signals on the public option created such an uproar.

byline.original: By JEFF ZELENY and CARL HULSE

docs.lead_paragraph: Health care rallies have suddenly become a rite of late summer. The one scheduled for Friday morning in downtown Orlando, Fla., has been advertised as featuring doctors angry about the prospect of lower Medicare payments. Many physicians of all sorts fear that a health care overhaul could reduce government payments in the Medicare and Medicaid programs.

headline.kicker: MAKING SENSE OF THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE

docs.abstract: Scheduled rally in Orlando, Fla, has been advertised as featuring doctors angry about prospect of lower Medicare payments; many physicians fear that health care overhaul could reduce government payments in Medicare and Medicaid programs; Orlando rally, organized by cardiologists, is focused on Medicare reimbursement cuts already proposed for Jan 2010, some of which are required by 1997 statute that can be overridden only by Congress (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It was the opposite of a boisterous public forum. Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Kathleen Sebelius, the health and human services secretary, met quietly Thursday with a few dozen doctors and nurses in Chicago at Mount Sinai Hospital, a nonprofit hospital on the West Side that serves many Medicaid and uninsured patients.
docs.abstract: Vice Pres Joseph R Biden Jr and Health and Human Services Sec Kathleen Sebelius meet with few dozen doctors and nurses at Mount Sinai Hospital in Chicago to discuss electronic health records, which Pres Obama says will eventually reduce medical costs; Biden photo (M)
docs.snippet: It was the opposite of a boisterous public forum.     Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Kathleen Sebelius, the health and human services secretary, met quietly Thursday with a few dozen doctors and nurses in Chicago at Mount Sinai Hospital, a...

docs.lead_paragraph: Some House Democrats are holding on to the idea of a public insurance option despite growing concern that their stance could jeopardize President Obama's effort to overhaul the health care system. Representative Raúl M. Grijalva, Democrat of Arizona, the co-chairman of the Congressional Progressive Caucus, and Representative Keith Ellison, right, Democrat of Minnesota, said Thursday that they would not support a bill that replaced the public insurance option with health insurance cooperatives. They called the co-op idea, favored by the Senate Finance Committee, a toothless substitute for a government-sponsored alternative.
docs.abstract: Reps Raul M Grijalva and Keith Ellison say they will not support health care bill that replaces public insurance option with health insurance cooperatives; Ellison photo (M)

byline.original: By JANIE LORBER and BERNIE BECKER

docs.lead_paragraph: In an appearance today with a conservative radio host, President Obama said he was confident that health care reform would pass, though he said he believed Republicans were obstructing the effort largely to deny his administration a significant political victory.

headline.main: Obama Still Optimistic on Health Care Overhaul

docs.abstract: The president insisted that health care legislation would pass despite Republican opposition.
docs.snippet: The president insisted that health care legislation would pass despite Republican opposition.

docs.lead_paragraph: Progressive lawmakers are clinging to the public insurance option despite growing concern that their resistance could jeopardize President Obama's overhaul of the health care system.

headline.main: Progressives Reaffirm Support for Public Option
